person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

person_231.name: JosephBlack
person_231.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

person_611.name: JamesSmithson
person_611.description: Born Jacques-Louis Macie in Paris; became James Louis Macie upon naturalizing to Britain and in 1800 adopted his father's original surname of Smithson. Wealthy natural son of the Duke of Nothumberland. Proprietor of the Royal Institution who wrote on chemistry. Bequeathed his money to the United States to found the Smithsonian Institution. FRSL.

person_149.name: CharlesHatchett
person_149.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_261.name: GregoryWatt
person_261.description: Youngest son of James Watt. Lodged with Davy's mother in Penzance during the winter of 1797-8 and became close friends with Davy.

person_146.name: JamesWatt
person_146.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_241.name: Johann FriedrichBlumenbach
person_241.description: Professor of Medicine at Göttingen University. Race theorist who applied comparative anatomy to classification of human races. ForMemRSL.

person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_1066.name: GeorgePaul
person_1066.description: Sir George Onesiphorus Paul, 2nd Baronet was an English prison reformer and philanthropist.

person_1005.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
person_1005.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

person_519.name: WilliamWhiston
person_519.description: English (unorthodox) theologian, historian, natural philosopher, and mathematician. A leading figure in promoting the ideas of Isaac Newton whom he succeeded as Lucasian Professor.

place_825.name: River Thames
place_825.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

place_237.name: Iceland
place_237.description: A Nordic island country between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

place_692.name: Bovey Formation (Devon)
place_692.description: The Bovey Formation in Devon contains lignite, a poor brown coal with a visibly woody structure.

place_887.name: Glasgow
place_887.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

place_373.name: Teesdale
place_373.description: Teesdale is a dale, or valley, in northern England.

place_306.name: Alston Moor
place_306.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

place_301.name: County Antrim
place_301.description: A county in north-eastern Northern Ireland.

place_126.name: Giant's Causeway
place_126.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

place_1193.name: Staffa
place_1193.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_1029.name: Durham, England
place_1029.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

place_1359.name: Northumberland
place_1359.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_990.name: Siberia
place_990.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges
